content: The "Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007" or the "K.T. Safety Act of 2007" requires the Secretary of Transportation to consider implementing safety standards for power windows on motor vehicles to prevent injuries or fatalities caused by obstructions. If deemed reasonable and practical, the Secretary will prescribe these standards within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must prescribe safety standards for power windows and panels to prevent injuries within 30 months of the Act's enactment. If no additional standards are deemed necessary, a report must be submitted to relevant committees explaining the decision. The Secretary must report to relevant committees on the reasons for not prescribing safety standards for power windows and panels within 30 months. Information on vehicles equipped with safety features must be made public. Additionally, a rulemaking to expand rearward visibility must be initiated within 12 months. The Secretary will initiate a rulemaking to expand rearward visibility within 12 months to reduce death and injury from backing incidents, especially involving small children and disabled persons, by revising Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 111. This may involve additional mirrors, sensors, or cameras. The Secretary will establish standards to expand rearward visibility for motor vehicles to reduce accidents involving small children and disabled persons. This may include additional mirrors, sensors, or cameras. Compliance with the safety standards must be achieved within 48 months of the final rule being issued. The Secretary will establish rearward visibility safety standards for motor vehicles to reduce accidents involving small children and disabled persons. Compliance must be achieved within 48 months of the final rule being issued, with priorities set based on data on backing incidents. The Secretary will issue regulations to prioritize certain types of motor vehicles in preventing backing incidents resulting in injury or death. Motor vehicles with automatic transmission manufactured after September 1, 2010, must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". After September 1, 2010, motor vehicles with automatic transmission must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". Violation of this requirement is treated as a violation of a motor vehicle safety standard and subject to enforcement by the Secretary. Motor vehicle manufacturers must submit information on noncompliant vehicles with automatic transmissions to the Secretary, who will then publish the make and model of these vehicles to the public. The Secretary must publish noncompliant motor vehicle information to the public within 30 days. Any vehicle not listed is presumed to comply. The definition of a motor vehicle excludes motorcycles and trailers. The term "motor vehicle" for safety standards excludes motorcycles, trailers, and vehicles over 10,000 pounds. The Secretary is required to establish a database on injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events within 12 months. The Secretary will establish a database of injuries and deaths in nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles, including information on the number, types, and causes of injuries and deaths, vehicle make and model details, and other relevant variables. This database will be made available to the public online and through other means. Additionally, a Child Safety Information Program will be implemented within 9 months. The Secretary will provide child safety information through a consumer program using data on nontraffic, noncrash injuries. This program aims to prioritize hazards to children and enhance database value. The Secretary will establish a consumer information program on child safety, utilizing data on nontraffic, noncrash injuries to prioritize hazards and provide information on risks like back over incidents and hyperthermia.
